format.name: KeywordFrequencyChecker
format.description: The argument value must contain the word 'end' exactly 1 time. The occurrences may be anywhere in the string. Case does not matter.

fn_schema.name: debug_program_code
fn_schema.description: Analyzes and debugs the provided program code to identify and fix errors.

code.description: The program code which needs to be debugged. The value must contain the word 'end' exactly once, anywhere in the string, regardless of case.

language.description: The programming language used for the code.

provide_solution.description: Whether to provide a solution or fix along with the debug analysis. Defaults to True.

user_queries:
I've been struggling to figure out why my Python script to process CSV files keeps throwing an error when I try to read the data. Here's the relevant part of my code:

import csv
with open('data.csv', 'r') as file:
    reader = csv.reader(file)
    for row in reader:
        print(row[0] + row[1])

It seems like everything should work but I get an index error on some rows. Could you please go through the code, identify what’s wrong, provide an explanation, and suggest what I should fix to make it work correctly?

I wrote a Ruby script to loop over a list of names and print a greeting for each, but it's throwing an undefined variable error. Here's the code:

names = ['Alice', 'Bob', 'Carol']
for name in names
    puts 'Hello, ' + names
end

Can you examine this Ruby code, explain why it's failing, and if you identify any issues, provide the corrected code? I need to understand exactly what’s wrong and how to resolve it.
